key_insights: Bottom-up GTM requires two steps: get ICs to love your product, then help them spread it within organizations
Build credibility with technical audiences by having technical experts create content, not marketers
Designer advocates (technical experts without quotas) significantly improve sales conversion rates
Focus on one distribution channel initially - for Figma it was Twitter where the design community already existed
Turn your biggest adoption blocker into your biggest advantage - design systems became Figma's key enterprise feature
Pricing should enable viral spread: unlimited collaborators/viewers, only charge for editors
You can't optimize your way to product-market-fit in early stages - focus on signal over metrics
Transparency and authenticity become harder but more important as you scale

memorable_quotes: You can't optimize your way to product market fit. I don't care at the early stages if something's optimized by 5% from an email.
If I understood it, it was probably too basic, or if I could have written it myself, it was probably too basic.

Four elements for organizational spread (easy sharing, advocates, operational unlock, champion nurturing)

summary: Claire Butler shares Figma's unique bottom-up go-to-market strategy, revealing how they built a multi-billion dollar business by first making individual contributors love the product, then helping them spread it within organizations through technical credibility, designer advocates, and community-driven growth.
